oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Papal Indulgence
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
Reign of Calixtus III
Manuscript on parchment
Bull of Papal Indulgence probably granted at St. Peter's in Rome sometime between 1455 and 1458. 21 long lines in a papal chancery hand, the name of the pope in large calligraphic capitals, decorative assenders in the first line. The turn-up at the bottom of the document is torn and rather worn.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Book of Hours
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Leaf from a French book of hours created in the mid-15th century. Twelve lines of Gothic text in Latin on vellum. Side 1 has an initial "C" in highly burnished gold on a multicolor ground. Side 2 has 12 lines of Gothic text with rubricating on the last line. The medieval book of hours, a collection of prayers and devotions, was the most popular devotional book of the later Middle Ages especially in the homes of wealthy families.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Postilla Super Epistolas et Evangelista
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
Explanations of the Gospels and Epistles. Latin text
in black letter type in double columns. Extensive
rubrication throughout the text and initials, all hand
painted in bright red ink. This early edition of the
Gospel commentaries of William of Paris, a popular
and learned theologian, was published in 1493 by
Anton Koberger. It is regarded as incunabula (from the first 50 years of printing in Europe).

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Norman Charter of Ardenne Abbey
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
Charter in which Walter de Agnell records that he is
conveying to Renardus de Villa Tierri,
justicar of Bayeux, lands which he holds from
Ardenne Abbey but admitting that he has
lost the original lease from the canons.
The Premonstratensian Abbey of Ardenne
inherited its rule from St. Agustine.
The document is written on the flesh side
of the parchment and folded at the bottom.
The appropriate horizontal slit is present,
but the seal and attachment are missing.
Side 2 of the document includes Walter de Agnell's
name in large lettering and
Renardus de Villa Tierri's name is on the bottom fold.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Leaf of Legal Manuscript
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Leaf from a Spanish legal manuscript. The manuscript was begun in Seville in 1604 and finished in 1641 in Mexico City. The vellum manuscript was begun by Alonso Perez, notary public of Santa Maria at the request of Alonso Lopez de Luna of Seville whose son Alonso de fonte Luna who was then in the public prison of Puerto de Santa Maria facing a charge of murder. His father (Alonso Lopez de Luna) hired Perez to demonstrate the noble lineage of the family in order to enjoy the judicial privileges of nobility. The page contains a large illuminated E and elaborate bordering, with initials in gold leaf. This document was once part of the library of the secretary of Maximilian I of Mexico (6 July 1832 - 19 June 1867).
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Perez, Alonso
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Manuscripts, Spanish; Titles of honor and nobility
Parchment

Government, Law & Politics

oai_dc:dc.dc:title:
Leaf 1 from the Nuremberg Chronicle or the Chronicle
of the World
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
The Nuremberg Chronicle presents human history
in six ages from the creation to the reign of Maximilian,
1493. A seventh age is based on the Revelation of St.
John. Folio XCV, recto shows Mary, the mother of
Jesus as decended from Joachim and Anne. Other
Biblical figures are depicted in this illustration. Herod,
ruler of Galilee is showen in the lower right.
Another prince is depicted in the lower left.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Schedel, Hartman, 1440-1528
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Religion; History;
Books; Book illustrations;
Joachim and Anne (first century); Herod Antipas, 25 BCE - 39 CE.; Maxmilian I, 1459-1519

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Leaf 2 from the Nuremberg Chronicle or the Chronicle of the World
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
The Nuremberg Chronicle presents human history
in six ages from the creation to the reign of Maximilian,
Holy Roman Emperor, 1493. A seventh age is based
on the Revelation story of St. John. Folio CXV, verso
shows St. Lucius and his queen in the upper
left of the page. Historians, theologians and
philosophers line the left and right margins of the page
(Pompeius Trogus, Theodosius, Appolonius,
Dionisius, Bishop of Corinth, Clemens, and Tertullian).

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Leaf 3 of the Nuremberg Chronicle, or the Chronicle of the World
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
The Nuremberg Chronicle presents human history in
six ages from the creation of the world to the reign of
Maximilian as Holy Roman Emperor in 1493.
A seventh age is based on the Revelation story of
St. John. Folio CXXXII presents images of four Roman
Emperors on the right side of the page. These are
Julian the Apostate, Jovianus, Valentinianus and Valens
covering the years 360 to 378 CE in Roman and
early Christian history.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Leaf 4 from the Nuremberg Chronicle, or the Chronicle of the World
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
The Nurember Chronicle presents human history
in six ages from from the creation to the coronation of
Maximilian as Holy Roman Enperor in 1493.
The seventh age of the world is only a few pages but
it tells of the coming of the Antichrist and the Last
Judgement as portrayed in the imagery of the
Revelation of St. John the Divine. This woodcut
fragment from folio CCLIX verso shows the arrival
of the false prophets and the struggle between the
angel and the dragon (Revelation, 12:7). This page
is a fragment. The upper part of the page, depicting the
struggle between the angel and dragon, is
missing.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Schedel, Hartman, 1440-1528
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Religion; History;
Books; Illustrations;
St. John the Divine, evangelist

student standing in the same location was used in

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Illuminated Patent of Nobility, Spain
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Illuminated patent of nobility issued to Diego Belarde de Aguilar on his own account and on behalf of his brother Juan, reciting the patent granted by Charles V and the services of their father Captain Rodrigo Belarde de Aguilar. The patent includes a finely-illuminated miniature of the Virgin within a red and blue decorative border (leaf 1r) and a full-page illuminated coat of arms (leaf 7v). There are also illuminated hands and gilt borders throughout, as well as notarial seals and later dockets (leaves 24-26, dated 1607).
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Antiphoner, Nativity of Mary
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A leaf from a Latin antiphoner. The five lines of music and verse are on a stave formed of five lines. Both of the hymn fragments represented on this leaf ("-tica dramatis" and "hodie nata") come from songs commonly sung on Marian feast days. The latter was (and still is) often sung on September 8th, the Nativity of Mary. The illumination of the "h" in "hodie" also suggests that this leaf was used on a Marian feast day, most likely September 8th.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown;

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Siena College Historic Image, Siena Seal, 1999
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The seal of the College has at the top Siena College and at the bottom A.D. (Latin, Anno Domini, English, the Year of Our Lord) 1937, the date of the College's founding. The name of the College and its location are written around the outer circle in Latin, the English translation being Seal of the College of St. Bernardine of Siena, Loudonville, New York. In the center of the logo is the monogram IHS in Greek script, with a cross and twelve rays speading out from the center. IHS are the first three letters of the Greek form of "Jesus." St. Bernardine of Siena (1380-1444), after whom the College is named, was an avid promoter of the Devotion to the Holy Name of Jesus, and the Province of Franciscans that founded Siena is the Holy Name Province. He was a reformer, within the Franciscan Order who stressed the importance of education. He became the "Apostle of Italy," preaching all over the peninsula to crowds of up to 30,000. He preached in Italian and in a style that reached the common man. He never hesitated to confront the high and the mighty in society and government, and worked to eliminate the practice of imprisoning debtors, and sought always to bring peace between constantly warring cities, urging them to follow the banner of Jesus, (the Holy Name Symbol with the cross and rays), rather than any city banner. The seal is located in the main lobby of the J. Spencer and Patricia Standish Library.
